It starts, as do many of the more interesting episodes of class 1-A’s dorm life, with Kaminari getting an Idea. Now, the collateral damage of said ideas is ordinarily borne by Kirishima, Sero, and Mina, because they’re Kaminari’s best friends and generally willing at any time to throw themselves headfirst into any and all dangerous, harebrained shenanigans.
This time, however, is different.
This time, Kaminari walks up to Todoroki in the hallway after class and says, “Dude, I need your help.”
Todoroki checks over his shoulder, twice, to verify that Kaminari is indeed talking to him. “Why?”
“Yesterday you asked Shinsou-kun if he was Aizawa-sensei’s son,” Kaminari says, as though that explains anything at all.
“...yes?”
“Make a hero conspiracy YouTube channel with me.”
Todoroki blinks. Then he blinks again. When he opens his eyes, Kaminari is still standing there and his smile hasn’t given an inch.
“I’m sorry, what.”
Kaminari shrugs casually, rubbing the back of his neck. “You just seem like you’re into that kind of thing! And I think it’d be fun! So what do ya say?”
Todoroki is silent for a long moment, until Kaminari starts to fidget slightly. Then he nods, once, and says, “Yeah, sure.”
Kaminari fist-pumps. “Hell yeah! You’re not gonna regret this, dude. Come on, I need to tell you some ideas I’ve got.”
Todoroki, still not entirely sure what’s happening, follows.
“So, I was thinking for our first episode we could do one of the top ten! That’d net us more attention, and everybody already knows who they are anyways. Uh, probably not Endeavor. But like, Best Jeanist? He’s pretty weird. I think maybe he’s got a mustache, and that’s why his turtleneck is pulled up all the way past his nose. Then when he’s out of costume, people won’t recognize him. I bet it’s a bad mustache, too.”
“Hm,” Todoroki says when Kaminari pauses for breath. “What makes you sure he has a mouth at all?”
Kaminari slowly turns to look at him, and whispers to himself, slightly awed, “This was the best idea ever.”

Todoroki is just finishing rereading the comments for the third time when Kaminari’s practically breaking down his door, yelling in incoherent excitement. Todoroki lets him in before he can wake up Bakugou next door and cause an incident, and they go over the comments together, making note of the criticisms. They’re both smiling, Kaminari huge and bright and Todoroki small and proud.
Todoroki starts writing actual scripts, outlining the episode so he doesn’t get distracted or lose his place. Kaminari visits Present Mic after class to ask for lessons in video editing. Jirou commandeers her camera back to film for them, and starts teaching them about lens options and audio settings.
The next day, Aizawa-sensei is collecting worksheets when he blinks down at the back of one, seemingly nonplussed, and says, “Todoroki.”
Todoroki looks up.
“What’s this list on the back of your homework?”
“Brainstorming,” Todoroki says.
“For what?”
Todoroki doesn’t miss a beat. “An extracurricular project.”
“What kind of extracurricular project would produce the words ‘Mount Lady is actually giant and her quirk is shrinking down to normal size?’” Aizawa-sensei asks, his voice totally flat.
“Oh, dude, that’s a great one!” Kaminari exclaims, drawing the attention of the classroom. “We should do that next. Hang on, what else is on there?”
And that’s how the rest of Class 1-A finds out about the project.

One by one, a few of their other classmates get roped into the production. Other then Jirou, who’s settled into her role as their camerawoman, there’s also Midoriya, whose encyclopedic knowledge of heroes and quirks makes him a common guest expert; Yaoyorozu and Iida, who are always willing to help with research; and Hagakure, who’s happy to be equipped with a Go-Pro and set to work trying to get evidence for various theories.
Most of the rest of class 1-A makes at least an appearance or two, be it by crossing through the background to get leftovers from the fridge and scowling at the camera (Bakugou) or belly-flopping onto the couch between the two hosts to insert their own opinion (Mina, frequently).
And slowly, steadily, their subscriber count begins to grow. As word gets around about the series and it increases in quality and popularity, they start getting more views, more likes, more comments. Some of them are trolls or spam, but the vast majority are genuine praise.
Todoroki’s not exactly sure just how it happens, but before long he’s the writer and co-host for one of the fastest-growing new shows on YouTube. He’s also suddenly friends with Kaminari, and he’s not quite sure how that happened, either.
But he’s definitely not complaining.

The idea for episode twenty comes, of all places, from Midoriya. He catches Todoroki’s attention one day during lunch, and says, “Have you ever thought about researching any older heroes for your show? Like from the Silver Age?”
“No,” Todoroki admits. His knowledge of heroes is extensive, but it’s limited to those that are currently active or very recently retired. Endeavor never saw any use in teaching him about dead or long-retired heroes who would never pose a threat to him, which means he barely knows anything about any heroes from before the time of All Might beyond what’s taught in history class. “It’s a good idea, though. Do you have one in mind?”
And Midoriya says, without a moment of hesitation, “Nana Shimura.”
It’s harder to research than the other episodes, even with Midoriya’s pre-existing knowledge to draw from. Nana Shimura is from before heroes were widely monitored and registered, so most information about her is vague, but Todoroki recruits Yaoyorozu to help him and Midoriya search, and little by little they build a story.
It’s quite a story.

From behind the camera, Jirou counts them down with hand signals: three, two, one, go. As soon as she hits the last, Kaminari breaks out into a beaming grin. “Hey guys! So, Hero Theory is going to be a little different today. There was a lot of demand on it for Twitter, especially after the last episode, so we’re doing a Q&A thing to celebrate hitting a hundred thousand subscribers!”
Todoroki nods. He looks a little more downcast and anxious than he usually does, not quite making eye contact with the camera.
“If you have a question, remember to submit it on Twitter under the hashtag #HTQA! Asshole questions will be smited with the fury of a thousand suns and one point three million volts!”
“Smote.”
“Huh?”
“Past tense of smite is smote,” Todoroki clarifies.
“Okay, then asshole questions will be smote. Let’s get this started!” Kaminari pulls out his phone and starts scrolling through the tag. “First question! One I’ve been asking for ages. Todoroki. Dude. Why don’t you have a Twitter yet?”
“I don’t need one,” Todoroki says, like it’s obvious.
“I’ve been trying,” Kaminari confides in an aside to the camera. “Dude’s intent on being a social media ghost. Second question: ‘are you two dating?’ Tragically, no. He’s hot, and I know, anybody would be lucky to have me, but Todoroki’s already got a cru-”
The last word is abruptly cut off into a stifled yell when he takes a couch pillow hard to the face. Todoroki, holding the pillow over Kaminari’s mouth with one hand, steals his phone with the other and scrolls through the next few questions while ignoring his co-host’s muffled complaints.
“‘Will you ever do theories on your classmates?’” he reads. “Maybe, but probably not. We already know them very well, and the hero license exam revealed that we place ourselves at a disadvantage if we release too much information about ourselves.” He scrolls down to the next question, and reads it silently with raised eyebrows before staring flatly into the camera. "Keep your questions appropriate."
Kaminari finally succeeds in shoving free of the pillow a few questions later, and seizes his phone back, settling into his seat again. “‘Where did the idea for the Adamant episode come from?’ I actually don’t know. Todoroki?”
“That one was Midoriya’s idea. Apparently he was a big fan of hers and wanted her to get more recognition.”
“Nice. ‘Who’s your cameraman?’ Camerawoman, actually. Say hi, Jirou!”
“Hey,” Jirou says, sounding bemused. A hand wearing chipped black nail polish appears in the shot, flashing a peace sign at the audience. Todoroki gives her a thumbs up.
“‘Question for both of you,’” Kaminari continues. “‘which episode was your favorite?’ Oh, uh, I was really proud of the Thirteen episode. We had a whole ton of nonbinary folks commenting to tell us they were happy with the way we handled all the theorizing about their gender! That was great!”
“The Adamant episode was mine,” Todoroki says. “It was harder to research, but it felt good to see a less glorified hero get the recognition she deserved.” He pauses, then adds, “Personally, though, I got the most satisfaction out of the Endeavor episode.”
Kaminari grins at that, before moving on to the next question. “‘Why don’t you guys have a Discord server?’ We should absolutely have a Discord server. That’s such a good idea. I’m making one as soon as we’re done with this.”
“Next question! This one’s for Todoroki too. Let me know if you’re not comfortable answering this, dude. ‘Why’d you decide to make the Endeavor episode?’”
Todoroki is quiet for a long moment before he answers, measuring his words. “Because… it’s important that people understand what sort of person he is. Even if he’s trying to be better now, and do better.” He shrugs a little. “After the Adamant episode proved that our show could actually have an impact, it just felt right.”
“Good answer, dude,” Kaminari says. “‘How did you get the idea to start this show?’ This one I can answer. Okay, so one of our classmates, Shinsou, you guys know him, he showed up in one of our episodes when we were talking about, uh…”
“Negative quirk stigma,” Todoroki says.
“Right, that. So he’s got kind of crazy hair and looks tired all the time, and Aizawa-sensei has crazy hair and looks tired all the time, so on the first day after Shinsou joined our class-“
“Is this necessary?”
“Yep!” Kaminari answers, sounding absolutely delighted. “On the first day after Shinsou joined our class, Todoroki walked up to him and asked him, to his face, if he was secretly Aizawa-sensei’s secret love child.”
“It wasn’t that unreasonable,” Todoroki mutters, looking away from the camera. “Aizawa-sensei was privately training him to get him into the hero course, and gave him a version of his capture weapon too.”
“So I saw this go down, and my immediate thought was, of course, dude, that guy would be a perfect co-host for a show about hero conspiracy theories.” Kaminari grinned widely, and hooked an arm around Todoroki’s shoulders, pulling him into a one-armed hug. “And look, I was right!”

The suggestion sheet is- well, really it’s Todoroki’s idea, but Mina’s fault. Once the show explodes in popularity, she and Sero develop a habit of ambushing Todoroki to suggest ideas. After the third time Todoroki very nearly sets them on fire, he gives up and yanks a piece of tape from Sero’s elbow to stick a sheet of notebook paper to their classroom wall.
For a time, the suggestion sheet serves as an anonymous idea dump for anybody in Class 1-A. Sooner or later, however, knowledge of it spreads to the rest of UA’s student body.
'Why Class 1-B is definitively better than the 1-A idiots' has shown up more than once, so Monoma, at least, definitely knows about it.
Most of the ideas on the sheet are usually nonsense even by the show’s spectacularly low standards, but Todoroki makes a point of checking the sheet every day after class regardless. Sometimes they have potential.
When he checks the list on Thursday, this is what it says:
“Huh,” Todoroki says.

The video is grainy, obviously filmed someplace with bad lighting on a shaky, handheld phone camera. The phone is held vertically, so the view is narrow. Nonetheless, the trademark scars and staples of the villain Dabi were clearly visible. The start of the video had caught Dabi mid-rant, and cackling, wheezing laughter was audible in the background.


“I’m going to kill that brat,” Dabi seethed. “I swear I am.”


A girl’s voice cooed from behind the phone. “Awwww, Touya-chan, don’t be like that!”


“I am going to set you on fire,” Dabi ground out, jabbing a finger at the phone. “Then I’m going to set him on fire. And then you,” he snapped at someone offscreen, “if you don’t stop FUCKING LAUGHING!”


The laughter did not stop. Blue sparks were falling from Dabi’s fingertips and he looked about two seconds from a conniption.


“Naaaaah,” the girl said. “You won’t. You looove us.”


“Don’t test me,” Dabi snarled. “Fuckin’ Shouto… When I finally off the old man, he’s not allowed to bitch about it. It’s his fault I have to deal with all of THIS now. Fuck this. Fuck everything. I need to go burn something.”


He stormed out of frame, and a few seconds later a door could be heard slamming. There was a pause, then a rustling sound, and the video flipped around to show Himiko Toga’s sickly golden eyes, flushed cheeks, and wide, mischievous smile.


“You’re welcome, Denki-kun, Shouto-kun!” she said with a wink. “For the record, I don’t think Best Jeanist has a mouth either.” She brandished a knife in front of the camera. “But I hope I can find out someday!”


She blew a kiss to the camera, and then the footage ended.

“Hey, Todoroki?” Kaminari tries, rapping his fist against the door. The wood feels cold beneath his knuckles, which is a good sign, because it means that Todoroki probably hasn’t set anything else on fire. “You in there?”
“Yes.”
“We, uh, put the fire out. In case you were wondering. The couch is a little charred, but it’s still not as bad as the time Bakugou and Kirishima tried to have a horror movie marathon.”
He’s rewarded by a soft huff of bemused laughter from the door, and surreptitiously fist-pumps in triumph before sobering again. “Dude… I’m sorry. This is my fault, I know you didn’t want to do the episode, and now it’s stirred up all this shit.”
“It’s not,” Todoroki starts, then stops, then starts again, “I’m- not angry. Really. I just… need to call my sister before she sees that on her own.”
“Oh, right, shit, yeah. You should do that. I just needed to ask, are you cool with me uploading the reaction video? I won’t if you don’t want me to.”
There’s a long pause.
“No, upload it.” There’s a hint of a smirk in his voice when Todoroki adds, “The comments will be amazing.”
“Dude, you are so right.”
He’s right. The comments are amazing.

The server proves to be an explosive success. It starts as just a place to chat about the latest episodes of hero theory and ask the creators questions, but it doesn’t take long for it to go completely off the rails in the best way. The entirety of Class 1-A joins it, as do (to everyone’s surprise) a few pro heroes, followed swiftly by a veritable flood of civilians. Todoroki and Kaminari are admins, while Jirou, Midoriya, Kirishima and Yaoyorozu get made moderators.
Todoroki mostly lurks on invisible mode, and inserts his opinion into conversations whenever it’s least expected, while Kaminari enthusiastically and constantly hypes up whatever the next episode will be, runs polls, and is generally a ray of hyperactive sunshine.
The suggestion sheet stays up on the classroom wall, of course, but now they have a constant stream of video ideas from the public as well. Most of the ideas are a bit too crazy even for them, Todoroki starts keeping a list on his phone of the good ones.
“Hey,” Kaminari says one day, while hanging upside down off of his bed, squinting at the results of the latest community poll on his phone. “People really want more villain episodes.”
“Mm?” Todoroki asks, glancing up from his English homework.
“Yeah! Like, yesterday I asked the server what their favorite episodes were, and the Adamant and Endeavor episodes were right up there at the top, but like the next two after that were the ones we did on Stain and Dabi.”
“I don’t think the Dabi episode was popular because he’s a villain,” Todoroki said. “That was because it actually turned out to be true.”
“Touché.”
